NINE TAKES THE FIRST CONTEST
Defeats Washington College,7 to 6—All
of the Black and Blue Runs Scored
in First Inning—Wasserman
Makes Good Showing.

In a game which began as a
sluggers' fest and ended as a
pitchers' battle, the Johns Hopkins baseball team won the first
game last Saturday afternoon
when it defeated Washington College by the score of 7 to 6.
The features of the game,
viewed from the Hopkins standpoint, were the steady pitching
of Wasserman and the sensational fielding of Benson. Brown,
the Washington College pitcher,
pitched a remarkable game • after
the first inning, holding the Black
and Blue team to a single hit.
The game opened disastrously
for Hopkins. Wallace won a base
which he did not deserve, and
Frampton was allowed to turn an
attempted sacrifice into an actual
base. Wallace scored on a sacrifice fly by Spedden. Errickson
doubled to center, and W.Wallace
achieved a homer, bringing in
three runs.
The inauspicious start, however,
seemed to bring the requisite
amount of fighting blood to the
Hopkins team. Porter was hit
by a pitched ball, immediately
stole second, and was advanced
to third by WOrthington's single.
Noble sent a single through center, bringing in two runs. Hobbs
was given a base on balls. Loose
playing on the part of the visitors
allowed Noble to score and Egerton to reach first. Benson hit
to Spedden, and was out at
first. Levin was given a base on
balls; he was followed by Howell,
who sent a single to left. Wasserman fanned. Errickson muffed
Porter's fly, allowing Howell to
score. Worthington made the
third out.
In the ninth,'Washington College began a rally, which, for a
time, threatened defeat to the
Black and Blue. Two runs were
scored. Two fnen were on bases,
and two were out, when the game
was ended by Egerton catching
W. Wallace's pop fly.

8.30 CLASSES WILL BEGIN AFTER EASTER;
SENIORS WHO ENLIST TO BE GRADUATED
Men Who Wish to Try for Commissions in Army to Be Given Final
Examinations Immediately—Corps to Be Excused
From Classes Every Wednesday.
At a faculty meeting held last Saturday morning, the petition,
conducted by THE NEWS-LETTER and signed by nearly three hundred
students, requesting that University classes be begun at 8.30, was
granted. It was decided, moreover, that the change in schedule be
begun immediately after the Easter vacation.
At the same time, it was unanimously agreed that the Hopkins
faculty should recommend to the Board of Trustees that the three
men in the academic department—William Skinner, Robert Merrick
and Howard Wilson—who have expressed a desire to take examinations for commissions in the United States Army, should be immediately examined upon the term's work so far, and, if they pass, should
be given their degrees without further delay. While official action can
only come from the Board of Trustees; there is not the slightest doubt
but that the recommendation of the faculty will be granted. Nor is there
any doubt as to the fact that the same privilege will be accorded to
all other 'Seniors who wish to join the colors.
The object in introducing the
change in schedule immediately is
two-fold. In the first place, the
earlier schedule is to be treated
somewhat as an experiment. If
it proves successful in the few
remaining months of this collegiate year it will be adopted in full
before the opening of the University next fall, when daylight practice will be most needed. Members of the faculty make no secret
of the fact that the success of the
experiment depends upon the way
in which it is accepted by the
student body. If the number of
latenesses shows any marked increase, the entire scheme may fail.
In the second place, earlier
classes for the remainder of the
year will prove of material advantage in the development of the
Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training Corps. The drills may now
not only continue earlier, but, due
to the increasing length of the
days, may also last longer.
The faculty took another action
designed to promote the training
of Hopkins students in deciding
that for the reaminder of the year
members of the battalion will be
excused from classes every Wednesday. Lieutenant Elliott plans
to put the corps through drills
and maneuvers throughout the
whole of this day.
The actions of the faculty are
regarded as• particularly significant, as showing the extent to
which the University stands ready
to co operate with ;the Government. It is rumored that the
steps taken on Saturday, unprecedented as they are in Hopkins'
history, will be but the first if
President Wilson calls upon the
country to prepare itself for actual hostilities.

While at the present time, with
President Wilson's address to
Congress still undelivered, it is
impossible to say just what Wilt
happen, even in the course of the
coming week, there seems to be no
idea of closing the University before the scheduled date. When
interviewed upon the subject,
Dean Brush gave it as his opinion
that, as matters now stand,
nothing could be gained by such a
course. Every opportunity will
be allowed for Hopkins students
to serve their country in whatever
way they choose, but, unless the
number of those who wish to take
the examinations for commissions
or to volunteer as privates comes
to include the majority of the attendants upon the. University,
classes will continue until June.
Dean Brush pointed out that a
very practical way of preparing
to serve their country is already
open to Hopkins men in the Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training
Corps. While not desirous of influencing the course of the men
who wanted to enlist, he said
that, in his opinion, they might
serve their country most, efficiently, unless, indeed, previous
training fitted them for some detailed service, by learning how to
become officers. •
As sufficiently indicated by the
measures taken last Saturday,
the corps is to be supported in
every way possible. Both the
faculty and the board of trustees
are ready to collaborate with
Lieut Elliott in all that he deems
necessary for the battalion's final
development. Should war be declared,. it is highly probable that
special arrangements will be made

ALUMNI CO DOWN TO DEFEAT
'Varsity Scores 10 Goals to Veterans' 3.
Shows an Unusually Strong Attack.
Whole Team Well Developed.
Outdoor Practice Tells.

The 'Varsity lacrosse team
opened its season auspiciously
last Saturday afternoon by defeating the Alumni, 10 to 3. Despite
the apparent one-sidedness of the
score the game was interesting,
for the veterans were full of fight
and kept the 'Varsity busy all the
time. Had they had the speed
and wind to match their knowledge of the game, they would have
given the younger men a much
closer battle.
Henry Frank, especially, gave
several pretty exhibitions of "how
they did it in the old days." Prevost Boyce and Alan Voshell, two
Of the stars of last year's team,
had been working out with the
men all winter, and kept the 'Varsity defense continually on the
jumpThe Alumni were handicapped
by the loss of Tommy Troxell,
their captain, who was able to
play only a few moments on account of an injury to his knee
which he sustained in practice
last week.
The most pleasing feature of
the 'Varsity's playing was their
splendid teamwork and knowledge
of the game, especially for so
early in the season. This is due
not only to the fact that most of
the men have played together before, but also because of the large
amount of hard outdoor work
made possible by the early arrival
of spring.
The Cornell game this Saturday
will be one of the hardest on the •
schedule. The Big Red team, who
were the champions of the Northern division of the league last
year, have almost all of their men
back, and have prospects for an
unusually strong team.
The 'Varsity midfield attack
worked especially well last Saturday. The men got the ball shortly
after the whistle was sounded,
and goals were caged by Hoffman,
Wolfe and Johnny Knipp within
a very few minutes. After that,
the Alumni settled down, and the
'Varsity were able to score only
one more goal during the half.
At the beginning of the second
period Henry Frank slipped the
first one by Hank Chalmers, who
put up a splendid game at goal
throughout the contest. In a few
minutes the 'Varsity steadied,
and started scoring again. Pretty
midfield work by the Suttons
worked the ball up toward the
posts, where several shots were
scored by the Knipp brothers

CORPS PROVIDED WITH RIFLES
To Receive Colors This Tuesday Afternoon—Practice March on Wednesday—Daily Two-Hour Drills
if War Is Declared.

On this Tuesday afternoon at
4.30 o'clock Dr. Ronald Abercrombie will present an American
flag to the Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training Corps. A parade.,
and review will be held by the
battalion as part of the ceremonies, and Lieut. Elliott will accept the flag in its behalf.
The corps is now drilling on
Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays from 4.30 to 5.30 P. M. If
war is declared drills will )3e held
every day except Sunday from 4
to 6 in the afternoon.
The corps will take an all-day
practice march this Wednesday.
First call will be sounded at 8.45
A. M., and assembly at 9 A. M.
The battalion will then proceed to
the neighborhood of Hamilton,
where tactical problems will be
studied and carried out. As the
corps will, not be dismissed until
5 P. M., its members are advised
to take lunch with them. On that
day all corps members will be excused from classes.
The applications of Captains
Darley, Thompson and Chesley
and Lieut. Baxley for second lieutenancies in the Officers' Reserve Corps have been accepted,
and it now remains for Lieut. Elliott to examine them for commissions. First Sergt. Freedlander,
one of Lieut. Elliott's assistants,
received word that the fact that
he was over forty-five excluded
him from a captaincy in the Officers' Reserve Corps, but he was
advised to apply for a commission
as major, which lie has proceeded
to do.
The long-expected 170 Krags
have at last arrived, and part of
the drill hour last Monday was
spent in removing the grease in
which they were packed. They
will, be carried on Wednesday's
hike.
During the past three weeks, a
number of changes have been
made in the roster of "non-corns."
Several corporals have been promoted to sergeants and three
have been made supply sergeants,
whose immediate duties will be
driving the commissary wagon on
Wednesday's march and attending to the "grub."
The bugle corps, under the able
instruction of Bugler-Sergeant
Warner, is improving, and several
of its members can blow most of
the calls with reasonable accuracy.
The companies had excellent ex• perience last week in advancing
as skirmishers through the woods •
about Homewood. The object was
to see if the long line, composed
of two companies, could emerge
on the opposite side of a dense
wood without breaking up. This
it succeeded in doing fairly well.

JUNIORS' FEAST PHILOSOPHIC

PHI BETA KAPPA MEN ELECTED

Dr. Slonimisky Compares American and
European Universities—Coach Murphy Sketches Plans for Hopkins'

6 Students Selected from Undergraduate
Department,7 from Graduate Department of Philosophy, 10 from Graduate Department of Medicine.

Athletic Development.

•

The"philosophers'banquet" held
by the junior class at the Hotel
Emerson on last Thursday night
was an affair highly unusual. The
menu for the dinner was made
out entirely in philosophical terms,
and each speaker and each member of the committee was designated by the name of some great
philosopher. ,
After the dinner, the toastmaster, Alexander Randall, president of the class, introduced Dr.
Slonimsky as the principal speaker
of the evening.
Dr. Slonomisky's talk dealt
mainly with a description of the
ideal university and an exhortation to Hopkins students to assist in making Johns Hopkins approach its ideal. He first compared the European and the
American university and showed
how different was the influence of
the university on society in this
country and abroad. There the
students are the leaders in all
radical reforms, and the generators of new thoughts and ideas.
In contrast, the American student while more attractive in personality is, nevertheless, not as
well developed along many lines.
American universities, Dr. Slonimsky said, were becoming professional schools for the grinding
out of engineers, doctors, lawyers,
etc., without teaching them anything of the cultural, classic side.
The universities in this century
should become the breeding places
for ideas and the instruments for
spreading the humanities.
Another prominent speaker was
Russell Murphy, or "Murph," next
year's football coach and athletic
advisor. He unfolded, in part,
the plan that he hopes to inaugurate next fall. He intends to look
to the future, to try to get as
many students as possible in the
habit of taking regular exercise,
and inducing them to continue
this after they leave college, thus
gradually tending to build up the
physical side of the men of this
country.
Robert Duncan also spoke, taking for his subject the "Glory of
the Class." He spoke of "Bob"
Layfleld and urged every member
of the class to follow their former
friend and classmate as an ideal.
"Hank" Chalmers was the next
speaker, using "Class Spirit" as
his theme. "Lefty" Taylor recited, with an appropriate introduction, his original poem on the
"Descent of Man." This amusing
piece presented Darwin's theories
in a striking way. Frank Sutton,
Alexander Wolfe, "Admiral" Jeff
Miller, Stuart Egerton, Henry
Evans and H. Sun also delivered
short extemporaneous talks.

The Layfield Memorial.

To those who knew him who
watched the brave fight that he
fought with death, the memory of
Robert Layfield can never become
dim. They will always remember
the sacrifice which he made for his
University; always to them he
will stand for the personification
of courage and loyalty. For those
men, Layfield needs no monument; his name is writ upon their
hearts in letters more enduring
than bronze.
Yet, for the generations of Hopkins students who know the story
of Layfield only as it has been
told to them, it is eminently fitting that his memory and the
things for which he stood should
be perpetuated in a tangible form.
Soon there will come the time
when not a student in the University has heard of Layfield but by
hearsay, when the knowledge that
a man once gave his life for Hopkins will become a knowledge impersonal — a knowledge . only
vaguely present in University consciousness. It was to keep that
knowledge before the eyes of future classes that the idea of the
memorial was conceived and carried out.
It is not the bare fact that Layfield sacrificed his life for his University that is so meaningful; it
was in the way in which he
met his death that the nobility of
the man shone forth so clearly.
For weeks he lay upon his bed,
paralyzed, his body encased in
plaster. Yet, until the very end,
he refused to surrender hope; with
the same unquenchable courage
that he had shown upon the football field, he fought long after his
doctors had given up the battle—
a fight filled with an anguish that

A few weeks ago President
Goodnow officially announced that
the Johns Hopkins University
stood prepared to serve the Government in whatever way it was
most fitted. The action taken by
the faculty last Saturday proved
conclusively that it was ready to
make that promise good, and to
make it good up to the hilt. In
themselves, the beginning of University classes at 8.30, the immediate granting of degrees to Seniors who wish to enlist and the
excusing of the members of the
corps from classes for an entire
day, are unprecedented enough
in University history, yet these
things are but the beginning—
steps taken before war has been
declared. There can be no possible doubt that if Hopkins does
not close before its scheduled
time, it will be only because of
the fact that the University can
serve the Government more efficiently by remaining open.
There was, however, a step
taken by the faculty last Saturday which, in its implications,
was even more significant than
the steps taken in regard to University matters. The letter dispatched to President Wilson by
sixty-three members of the faculty
is far more than the expression
of the opinions of sixty-three individuals. The signers of that
letter represent one of the most
intellectual group of men in the
world—the fact that they have
gone on record as in favor both
of war with Germany and of universal military training has a far
greater meaning than the mere
number of the men who affixed
their signatures to the plea would
in itself imply.
Obviously, the Hopkins undergraduate body has not the weight
in matters of national import that
would be accorded to the Hopkins faculty, but THE NEWS-LETTER believes that a canvass of the

The Season Opens.

There is something peculiarly
thrilling in the sight which Homewood Field presents on a spring
Saturday afternoon. The splatter
of colors on the grandstands, the
black fringe surrounding the oval,
the smooth expanse of green turf,
the murmur of many voices, the
cheers,the tense silence that comes
over the stands when the attack
is close upon the goal—surely,this
is not one of the most unpicturesque phases of college life.
-The game of lacrosse, too, which
Hopkins has made so distinctively
its own—no form of athletics, perhaps, is more breath-checking in
its intensity, and yet, more open
in its style of play. Other universities have failed as yet to realize
the beauty of the game—have kept
it as one of their minor sports;
Hopkins men have known for
generations that there can be no
thrill greater than the thrill which
comes when stick clashes with
stick, when lithe bodies dart down
the field, passing the ball between
them, when the quick swing and
the rocking tell that the attack
has been intercepted. There is an
exhilaration to the game, played
as Hopkins men play it, which no
other sport can surpass—the keen
appreciation the grandstands experience in watching the perfect
co-ordination of mind and muscle
is as undiluted a tribute to beauty
as ever Greek paid to Doric
temple.
Some there are who hold that
the activities of a college should
be restricted to lines strictly academic, who regard the enthusiasm
engendered over the success of
college teams as enthusiasm misplaced, and the energy consumed
in the development of those teams
as energy wasted. To such onlookers life must seem a drab and
,colorless thing, iron-bound with
duties, lacking all buoyancy and
gladness. Existence to them must
be something to be endured; they
must regard it with an immutable
seriousness—assuredly, they can
never realize the gifts the poets
bring.
Long ages ago, shaggy-breasted
men fought for their lives with
crawling, horny-scaled reptiles,
and, in the fight, first tasted the
joy that is inherent in combat. A
few thousand years later, the
knight donned burnished armor,
pinned a glove upon his crest, and
rode forth upon his palfrey to
bring the world to his lady's feet..
Always has there been the keen,
clean joy of fighting, the call of
the blood that must be answered,
the victories that must be won by
strength of arm. Today, the call
finds its legitimate expression
upon a grassy oval, bloodless; but
let the caviler never say that the
spirit which evokes the sports of
college is a thing newly come upon
the earth, nor yet a thing which
can lightly and safely be undermined.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—The athletic situation at
our University has, during the
past few months, been subject to
so much criticism that I would
only repeat what someone else has
said before me, were it not for the
fact that I desire to discuss the
subject from a point of view entirely different from that assumed
by other critics. The object of an
athletic policy is certainly not
mere winning of games, as so
many assume, but is the physical
development of the college student. We should be glad on this
score that we have none of those
"athletic scholarships" so common
in most universities where the
athletic policy wins games. The
whole system however, tends to
those who have dedevelop only'
cided athletic ability, leaving to
the rest the opportunity for exercise only on the rooting stands.
Hopkins suffers from this less,
perhaps, than other colleges, but
we are now at a point of change
and must prepare for the eventuality of a larger student-body. A
university is not an athletic training camp which should specialize
on those who have athletic talents.
It is a place of intellectual specialization and should see that
sound bodies are provided for
good minds—not following the ordinary fallacy of trying to improve the mind by making a
strong body stronger.
The tendency in athletic matters should be to lay more and
more emphasis upon interclass
contests and away from 'varsity
sports. Interclass athletics avoids
any danger of professionalization
and attracts far greater numbers.
It may be urged that one could
not get up as much enthusiasm
about interclass contests as interuniversity ones. There is really
no reason why this should be. Objectively considered there is just
as much to be enthusiastic about
in both.
This brings me to a criticism
directed more against the studentbody as a whole than against the
athletic policy. We realize how
foolish it would be to become excited about interclass contests,
and yet we yell ourselves hoarse
about some football game. Is it
not a disgrace that we can work
ourselves into such a frenzy as to
believe that the winning of a
game deserves a parade while we
take no notice whatsoever of the

Russian revolution, the most glorious event of a century?
There is, of course, no institution at our college that is perfect,

Men Who Wish to Try for Commissions in Army to Be Given Final
Examinations Immediately—Corps to Be Excused
From Classes Every Wednesday.
At a faculty meeting held last Saturday morning, the petition,
conducted by THE NEWS-LETTER and signed by nearly three hundred
students, requesting that University classes be begun at 8.30, was
granted. It was decided, moreover, that the change in schedule be
begun immediately after the Easter vacation.
At the same time, it was unanimously agreed that the Hopkins
faculty should recommend to the Board of Trustees that the three
men in the academic department—William Skinner, Robert Merrick
and Howard Wilson—who have expressed a desire to take examinations for commissions in the United States Army, should be immediately examined upon the term's work so far, and, if they pass, should
be given their degrees without further delay. While official action can
only come from the Board of Trustees; there is not the slightest doubt
but that the recommendation of the faculty will be granted. Nor is there
any doubt as to the fact that the same privilege will be accorded to
all other 'Seniors who wish to join the colors.
The object in introducing the
change in schedule immediately is
two-fold. In the first place, the
earlier schedule is to be treated
somewhat as an experiment. If
it proves successful in the few
remaining months of this collegiate year it will be adopted in full
before the opening of the University next fall, when daylight practice will be most needed. Members of the faculty make no secret
of the fact that the success of the
experiment depends upon the way
in which it is accepted by the
student body. If the number of
latenesses shows any marked increase, the entire scheme may fail.
In the second place, earlier
classes for the remainder of the
year will prove of material advantage in the development of the
Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training Corps. The drills may now
not only continue earlier, but, due
to the increasing length of the
days, may also last longer.
The faculty took another action
designed to promote the training
of Hopkins students in deciding
that for the reaminder of the year
members of the battalion will be
excused from classes every Wednesday. Lieutenant Elliott plans
to put the corps through drills
and maneuvers throughout the
whole of this day.
The actions of the faculty are
regarded as• particularly significant, as showing the extent to
which the University stands ready
to co operate with ;the Government. It is rumored that the
steps taken on Saturday, unprecedented as they are in Hopkins'
history, will be but the first if
President Wilson calls upon the
country to prepare itself for actual hostilities.

While at the present time, with
President Wilson's address to
Congress still undelivered, it is
impossible to say just what Wilt
happen, even in the course of the
coming week, there seems to be no
idea of closing the University before the scheduled date. When
interviewed upon the subject,
Dean Brush gave it as his opinion
that, as matters now stand,
nothing could be gained by such a
course. Every opportunity will
be allowed for Hopkins students
to serve their country in whatever
way they choose, but, unless the
number of those who wish to take
the examinations for commissions
or to volunteer as privates comes
to include the majority of the attendants upon the. University,
classes will continue until June.

very practical way of preparing

open to Hopkins men in the Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training

who wanted to enlist, he said
that, in his opinion, they might
serve their country most, efficiently, unless, indeed, previous

become officers. •

On this Tuesday afternoon at
4.30 o'clock Dr. Ronald Abercrombie will present an American
flag to the Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training Corps. A parade.,
and review will be held by the
battalion as part of the ceremonies, and Lieut. Elliott will accept the flag in its behalf.
The corps is now drilling on
Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays from 4.30 to 5.30 P. M. If
war is declared drills will )3e held
every day except Sunday from 4
to 6 in the afternoon.
The corps will take an all-day
practice march this Wednesday.
First call will be sounded at 8.45
A. M., and assembly at 9 A. M.
The battalion will then proceed to
the neighborhood of Hamilton,
where tactical problems will be
studied and carried out. As the
corps will, not be dismissed until
5 P. M., its members are advised
to take lunch with them. On that
day all corps members will be excused from classes.
The applications of Captains
Darley, Thompson and Chesley
and Lieut. Baxley for second lieutenancies in the Officers' Reserve Corps have been accepted,

one of Lieut. Elliott's assistants,
received word that the fact that
he was over forty-five excluded
him from a captaincy in the Officers' Reserve Corps, but he was
advised to apply for a commission
as major, which lie has proceeded
to do.
The long-expected 170 Krags
have at last arrived, and part of
the drill hour last Monday was
spent in removing the grease in
which they were packed. They
will, be carried on Wednesday's
hike.
During the past three weeks, a
number of changes have been
made in the roster of "non-corns."
Several corporals have been promoted to sergeants and three
have been made supply sergeants,
whose immediate duties will be
driving the commissary wagon on
Wednesday's march and attending to the "grub."
The bugle corps, under the able
instruction of Bugler-Sergeant
Warner, is improving, and several
of its members can blow most of
the calls with reasonable accuracy.
The companies had excellent ex• perience last week in advancing
as skirmishers through the woods •
about Homewood. The object was
to see if the long line, composed
of two companies, could emerge
on the opposite side of a dense
wood without breaking up. This

The"philosophers'banquet" held
by the junior class at the Hotel
Emerson on last Thursday night
was an affair highly unusual. The
menu for the dinner was made
out entirely in philosophical terms,
and each speaker and each member of the committee was designated by the name of some great
philosopher. ,
After the dinner, the toastmaster, Alexander Randall, president of the class, introduced Dr.
Slonimsky as the principal speaker
of the evening.
Dr. Slonomisky's talk dealt
mainly with a description of the
ideal university and an exhortation to Hopkins students to assist in making Johns Hopkins approach its ideal. He first compared the European and the
American university and showed
how different was the influence of
the university on society in this
country and abroad. There the
students are the leaders in all
radical reforms, and the generators of new thoughts and ideas.
In contrast, the American student while more attractive in personality is, nevertheless, not as
well developed along many lines.
American universities, Dr. Slonimsky said, were becoming professional schools for the grinding
out of engineers, doctors, lawyers,
etc., without teaching them anything of the cultural, classic side.
The universities in this century
should become the breeding places
for ideas and the instruments for
spreading the humanities.
Another prominent speaker was
Russell Murphy, or "Murph," next
year's football coach and athletic
advisor. He unfolded, in part,
the plan that he hopes to inaugurate next fall. He intends to look
to the future, to try to get as
many students as possible in the
habit of taking regular exercise,
and inducing them to continue
this after they leave college, thus
gradually tending to build up the
physical side of the men of this
country.
Robert Duncan also spoke, taking for his subject the "Glory of
the Class." He spoke of "Bob"
Layfleld and urged every member
of the class to follow their former
friend and classmate as an ideal.
"Hank" Chalmers was the next
speaker, using "Class Spirit" as
his theme. "Lefty" Taylor recited, with an appropriate introduction, his original poem on the
"Descent of Man." This amusing
piece presented Darwin's theories
in a striking way. Frank Sutton,
Alexander Wolfe, "Admiral" Jeff
Miller, Stuart Egerton, Henry
Evans and H. Sun also delivered
short extemporaneous talks.

The Layfield Memorial.

To those who knew him who
watched the brave fight that he
fought with death, the memory of
Robert Layfield can never become
dim. They will always remember
the sacrifice which he made for his
University; always to them he
will stand for the personification
of courage and loyalty. For those
men, Layfield needs no monument; his name is writ upon their
hearts in letters more enduring
than bronze.
Yet, for the generations of Hopkins students who know the story
of Layfield only as it has been
told to them, it is eminently fitting that his memory and the
things for which he stood should
be perpetuated in a tangible form.
Soon there will come the time
when not a student in the University has heard of Layfield but by
hearsay, when the knowledge that
a man once gave his life for Hopkins will become a knowledge impersonal — a knowledge . only
vaguely present in University consciousness. It was to keep that
knowledge before the eyes of future classes that the idea of the
memorial was conceived and carried out.
It is not the bare fact that Layfield sacrificed his life for his University that is so meaningful; it
was in the way in which he
met his death that the nobility of
the man shone forth so clearly.
For weeks he lay upon his bed,
paralyzed, his body encased in
plaster. Yet, until the very end,
he refused to surrender hope; with
the same unquenchable courage
that he had shown upon the football field, he fought long after his
doctors had given up the battle—
a fight filled with an anguish that

Evidence.

A few weeks ago President
Goodnow officially announced that
the Johns Hopkins University
stood prepared to serve the Government in whatever way it was
most fitted. The action taken by
the faculty last Saturday proved
conclusively that it was ready to
make that promise good, and to
make it good up to the hilt. In
themselves, the beginning of University classes at 8.30, the immediate granting of degrees to Seniors who wish to enlist and the
excusing of the members of the
corps from classes for an entire
day, are unprecedented enough
in University history, yet these
things are but the beginning—
steps taken before war has been
declared. There can be no possible doubt that if Hopkins does
not close before its scheduled
time, it will be only because of
the fact that the University can
serve the Government more efficiently by remaining open.
There was, however, a step
taken by the faculty last Saturday which, in its implications,
was even more significant than
the steps taken in regard to University matters. The letter dispatched to President Wilson by
sixty-three members of the faculty
is far more than the expression
of the opinions of sixty-three individuals. The signers of that
letter represent one of the most
intellectual group of men in the
world—the fact that they have
gone on record as in favor both
of war with Germany and of universal military training has a far
greater meaning than the mere
number of the men who affixed
their signatures to the plea would
in itself imply.
Obviously, the Hopkins undergraduate body has not the weight
in matters of national import that
would be accorded to the Hopkins faculty, but THE NEWS-LETTER believes that a canvass of the
students at the present time
would show in most conclusive
fashion that the opinions of Hopkins students coincide very remarkably with the opinions of
Hopkins professors.

The Season Opens.

There is something peculiarly
thrilling in the sight which Homewood Field presents on a spring
Saturday afternoon. The splatter
of colors on the grandstands, the
black fringe surrounding the oval,
the smooth expanse of green turf,
the murmur of many voices, the
cheers,the tense silence that comes
over the stands when the attack
is close upon the goal—surely,this
is not one of the most unpicturesque phases of college life.
-The game of lacrosse, too, which
Hopkins has made so distinctively
its own—no form of athletics, perhaps, is more breath-checking in
its intensity, and yet, more open
in its style of play. Other universities have failed as yet to realize
the beauty of the game—have kept
it as one of their minor sports;
Hopkins men have known for
generations that there can be no
thrill greater than the thrill which
comes when stick clashes with
stick, when lithe bodies dart down
the field, passing the ball between
them, when the quick swing and
the rocking tell that the attack
has been intercepted. There is an
exhilaration to the game, played
as Hopkins men play it, which no
other sport can surpass—the keen
appreciation the grandstands experience in watching the perfect
co-ordination of mind and muscle
is as undiluted a tribute to beauty
as ever Greek paid to Doric
temple.
Some there are who hold that
the activities of a college should
be restricted to lines strictly academic, who regard the enthusiasm
engendered over the success of
college teams as enthusiasm misplaced, and the energy consumed
in the development of those teams
as energy wasted. To such onlookers life must seem a drab and
,colorless thing, iron-bound with
duties, lacking all buoyancy and
gladness. Existence to them must
be something to be endured; they
must regard it with an immutable
seriousness—assuredly, they can
never realize the gifts the poets
bring.
Long ages ago, shaggy-breasted
men fought for their lives with
crawling, horny-scaled reptiles,
and, in the fight, first tasted the
joy that is inherent in combat. A
few thousand years later, the
knight donned burnished armor,
pinned a glove upon his crest, and
rode forth upon his palfrey to
bring the world to his lady's feet..
Always has there been the keen,
clean joy of fighting, the call of
the blood that must be answered,
the victories that must be won by
strength of arm. Today, the call
finds its legitimate expression
upon a grassy oval, bloodless; but
let the caviler never say that the
spirit which evokes the sports of
college is a thing newly come upon
the earth, nor yet a thing which
can lightly and safely be undermined.

For the Goucher girl the enticement of the gleaming dance floor,
even the lure of the spring bonnet,
according to the Goucher Weekly,
have come to be as nothing. In
their place has come—the top.
The Weekly tells it thus:
"'In the spring a young "girl's"
fancy lightly turns to thoughts
of'—tops, evidently. Formerly it
was gaily flowered hats, dazzling
sweaters, long walks in shady
woods, dips in some,icy pool, love
sonnets—or even an unconscious
desire for vacation—which attracted her, but now, it seems, she
is a prey to the top craze.
Green tops, red tops, purple tops,
yellow tops, penny tops or 'two
for fives,' in fact every kind
known to the most youthful of
boys, are seen whizzing, whirring,
spinning about Goucher.
"Childhood has indeed returned.
but not such a childhood as we experienced, for that consisted of
the very feminine occupation of
'playing dolls.' But now—walking from class she dives into her
pockets and whips out .a top,
winds about it an enlongated
string, and with newly acquired
dexterity spins it joyously on the
pavement. In class she pats it
fondly where it nestles in a pocket
and dreams of future tricks toteach it, thereby surpassing her
less skillful classmates. Indeed,
like spring,the top craze has come
to stay."

At the present time there seems
to be no conceivable doubt but
that, in one form or another, the

which will not only set a precedent for all future classes, but
which, as far as its own significance is concerned, will, at some
future date, play no mean part in
the University's finances.
What is perplexing the class,
however, is the question as to
whether it would be better to create the fund by means of each
man taking out an endowment insurance policy, as was suggested
when the plan was first broached
at the senior banquet, or whether,
all things considered, it might not
be more advisable to make the'
yearly payments to .which each
man pledges himself payable direct to the University.
It seems to be the general concensus of opinion that, under the
second plan, it would be possible
to create a greater fund for the
University than could be secured
through the insurance plan. The
only point is whether the men in
the class, in future years, would
be more liable to pay the money to
the University directly than, to
pay the premiums on a policy
which, they would know, could
never bear full results if the payments were discontinued. If the
payments would be made directly
to the University there would, of
course, be a separate account created into which each. yearly deposit would be paid and whichi
could not be drawn upon by theUniversity until the time set by
the class had elapsed.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—The athletic situation at
our University has, during the
past few months, been subject to
so much criticism that I would
only repeat what someone else has
said before me, were it not for the
fact that I desire to discuss the
subject from a point of view entirely different from that assumed
by other critics. The object of an
athletic policy is certainly not
mere winning of games, as so
many assume, but is the physical
development of the college student. We should be glad on this
score that we have none of those
"athletic scholarships" so common
in most universities where the
athletic policy wins games. The
whole system however, tends to
those who have dedevelop only'
cided athletic ability, leaving to
the rest the opportunity for exercise only on the rooting stands.
Hopkins suffers from this less,
perhaps, than other colleges, but
we are now at a point of change
and must prepare for the eventuality of a larger student-body. A
university is not an athletic training camp which should specialize
on those who have athletic talents.
It is a place of intellectual specialization and should see that
sound bodies are provided for
good minds—not following the ordinary fallacy of trying to improve the mind by making a
strong body stronger.
The tendency in athletic matters should be to lay more and
more emphasis upon interclass
contests and away from 'varsity
sports. Interclass athletics avoids
any danger of professionalization
and attracts far greater numbers.
It may be urged that one could
not get up as much enthusiasm
about interclass contests as interuniversity ones. There is really
no reason why this should be. Objectively considered there is just
as much to be enthusiastic about
in both.
This brings me to a criticism
directed more against the studentbody as a whole than against the
athletic policy. We realize how
foolish it would be to become excited about interclass contests,
and yet we yell ourselves hoarse
about some football game. Is it
not a disgrace that we can work
ourselves into such a frenzy as to
believe that the winning of a
game deserves a parade while we
take no notice whatsoever of the

Russian revolution, the most glorious event of a century?
There is, of course, no institution at our college that is perfect,
and it would be both hopeless and
foolish for me to attempt to criticise them all. Yet I feel that
there are many things about the
more important institutions which
had better be said. Since I am
approaching these matters in a
thoughtful -and objective manner,
I ask that those of my fellow-students who read these letters will
meet me half way with corresponding lack of passion and
prejudice.
As an agency for "social welfare" the Y. M. C. A. at college is
undoubtedly excellent. For its
intention to combat against the
skepticism and agnosticism that
so often comes with college education it deserves the highest
praise. Yet, when we consider it
apart from its intention, we must
regretfully recognize that it is one
of the strong forces against the
progressive thought and intellectuality of our life. One might
expect that the Y. M. C. A. would
inculcate in its members the
great ideals of humanity—charity,
tolerance; yet it is among the
members of this organization that
one finds the most intense and
fanatical intolerance. Whether
the Y. M. C. A. encourages the
growth of these prejudices or not,
their continued existence bears
testimony to a signal failure in
what should be its highest purpose.
I am at a loss to explain this
failure unless the reason is to be
found in the frantic efforts of the
Y. M. C. A. in the face of the
great forces of skepticism to preserve anything, so that in the fear
of thinking too fast it refuses to
think at all, and in attempting to
keep the faith, it preserves also
the prejudices and childishness of
the Sunday-school.
During the last year the Menorah Society has attained quite
some prominence as a part of the
college life of our Hebrew fellowstudents. It seems to me that
this organization, by segregating
that part of our student-body,
helps to preserve racial prejudices
in much the same way that the
fraternities help to preserve class
prejudice. In European universities and in most of our American institutions the Hebrews are
among the most active forces for
thought and progress. This function they should exercise also at
Hopkins.

More than fifty enthusiastic
Hopkins students assembled last
Friday night in the Mechanical
Engineering Building to hear a
plan whereby a Johns Hopkins
unit of the Naval Coast Defense
Reserve could be formed. An officer of the local naval recruiting
station described the work of the
"mosquito fleet" and its inducements, and took the names of
those who manifested interest.
The Hopkins unit, if formed,
would be a part of the Fifth
Naval District, which comprises
Maryland, Delaware, the District
of Columbia, Virginia, North
Carolina and South Carolina.
Its particular work would consist largely in patrolling the
Chesapeake Bay and surrounding
waters. Probably two or three
boats would be manned by this
unit, which would serve as harbor, mine or coast patrols, cooperate with United States submarines and aircraft, act as despatch boats and pursue hostile.
submarines.
In size, the boats, probably
either yachts or motor powerboats, would range from forty to
one hundred and ten feet long,
and the crews would vary from
five to ten men. Each boat would
be manned by an experienced ensign, several Hopkins students as
petty officers, a gunner's mate, a
boatswain and a few experienced
seamen.
The recruiting officer remarked
'that each of the Hopkins contingent would have a good chance
to be chief petty officers. He also
quoted a navy man as saying that
if a college man is given fifteen
minutes' instruction he May make
a better sailor than one who has
served before the mast for fifteen
years.
The members of the unit would
enroll in the Naval Coast Defense
Reserve for four years, but could
only be called out in case of actual war or emergency. Moreover,
they could not be transported to
another district or to another
branch of the naval service without their own sanction. Should
the unit be established, its prospective members, after enrollment
at the recruiting office, would
be given ten days' training under
the direction of the commandant
of the Fifth Naval District. In
